newsitem.title: CANADA: Toronto stocks surge to 58th record close of 1996.
newsitem.headline: Toronto stocks surge to 58th record close of 1996.

text.p: Toronto stocks surged to their 58th record close of the year on Friday as a bank-led rally overwhelmed a drop in gold prices.
The TSE 300 Composite Index jumped 49.65 points to finish at 5870.56, easily eclipsing the previous closing record set on Thursday.
The key 300 Index also set an intraday high of 5880.15.
Trading was brisk with 118 million shares changing hands worth C$1.8 billion ($1.34 billion).
"It was an option expiry day so obviously you had a lot of emotion that went into the market," said Ron Meisels, president of P and C Holdings Ltd. in Montreal.
The financial services group continued to rebound after correcting earlier this week. The sector added nearly 90 points, or 1.7 percent, to close at 5388.
"All the banks sold off due to profit taking in the last few days. Now, we're seeing a wave of buying, but it hasn't taken them to new highs," Meisels said.
Other strong groups included consumer products, communications, base metals and energy issues.
The weak side was led by transportation and precious metals which weakened along with sagging gold prices.

* Among Canada's big banks, Royal Bank of Canada rose 0.90 to 46.95 on 2.07 million shares. Toronto-Dominion Bank added 0.95 to 34.85 on 1.6 million shares, while National Bank of Canada gained 0.40 to 14.15 on 2.6 million shares.

* Bre-X Minerals Ltd. sank 1 to 20.90 after the gold miner said Friday an Indonesian partner in its huge Busang gold deposit may file a lawsuit in Alberta against Bre-X and 19 others over an ownership dispute.
* Dreco Energy Services Ltd. class A topped the net-gainers list, jumping 6.95 to 43 in light volume.
Other buoyant energy stocks included Renaissance Energy Ltd., up 1.25 at 45.75 and NOVA Corp which added 0.10 to 11.95 on 2.6 million shares.
* Active issues were topped by Kinross Gold which edged 0.05 higher to 10.10 in trade of 5.05 million shares.
Kinross said on Thursday a syndicate agreed to sell C$200 million ($150 million) of its unsecured convertible debentures bearing 5.5 percent and maturing December 5, 2006.
